comments.author: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com
comments.text:
470mb of the JS GC heap is unused but not decommitted.  That sucks.  :(

Do you have any reason to believe that this is an issue with Firefox and not the site?  Does another browser do better than us here?

(Thanks for including about:support, by the way.  The list of extensions helps a lot.)
comments.raw_text:
470mb of the JS GC heap is unused but not decommitted.  That sucks.  :(

Do you have any reason to believe that this is an issue with Firefox and not the site?  Does another browser do better than us here?

(Thanks for including about:support, by the way.  The list of extensions helps a lot.)
comments.creator: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com

comments.text: I have the site open in Google Chrome and in Opera and will report back at the end of the day how it went.
comments.author: dburns@mozilla.com
comments.raw_text: I have the site open in Google Chrome and in Opera and will report back at the end of the day how it went.
comments.creator: dburns@mozilla.com
dburns@mozilla.com
comments.raw_text:
after a couple hours Opera is leaking and showing similar spikes. I am using Opera 11.52. See screen shot. Unfortunately Opera doesnt show memory like we do so cant give you any meaningful info.

Google Chrome is also leaking but no where nearly as badly as Opera is. In the same time that Opera has been open, Google Chrome is only at 170MB. CPU spikes go to ~20% while Opera are going to 60% now.

Chrome about:memory

About memory Measuring memory usage in a multi-process browser

317,440k	293,888k	225,340k	4,448,256k
Opera

(Bug: We seriously overcount our own memory usage: Issue 25454.)

comments.author: dburns@mozilla.com
comments.text: I *think* the issue could be with the site since its using websockets where possible so there might be a call back manipulating the DOM and not that might not be cleaning up.
comments.raw_text: I *think* the issue could be with the site since its using websockets where possible so there might be a call back manipulating the DOM and not that might not be cleaning up.

comments.text:
> CPU spikes go to ~20% while Opera are going to 60% now.

How does Firefox's CPU usage compare?

481mb for FF versus 357mb for Opera doesn't seem so bad, especially since Nightly is running as a 64-bit process.

Chrome is using 171mb for the page, but an additional 94mb for the browser.  So the number we should be using for comparison is 265mb (minus shared memory, I guess).

Anyway, Firefox is worse here, but this looks like a dupe of the work described in [1].  You may want to revisit this bug after some of those changes land.

[1] http://blog.mozilla.com/nnethercote/2011/11/01/spidermonkey-is-on-a-diet/
comments.author: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com
comments.creator: justin.lebar+bug@gmail.com
comments.raw_text:
> CPU spikes go to ~20% while Opera are going to 60% now.

How does Firefox's CPU usage compare?

481mb for FF versus 357mb for Opera doesn't seem so bad, especially since Nightly is running as a 64-bit process.

Chrome is using 171mb for the page, but an additional 94mb for the browser.  So the number we should be using for comparison is 265mb (minus shared memory, I guess).

Anyway, Firefox is worse here, but this looks like a dupe of the work described in [1].  You may want to revisit this bug after some of those changes land.

[1] http://blog.mozilla.com/nnethercote/2011/11/01/spidermonkey-is-on-a-diet/

comments.creator: dburns@mozilla.com
comments.raw_text:
While revisiting this bug I am still seeing these spikes but not as much. I have noticed that if I watch a build in progress the browser become jerky and memory usage rises sharply. e.g. http://travis-ci.org/#!/AutomatedTester/browserid/builds/733070

This does a bit of DOM manipulation on websocket events so that *could* be related.

Let me know what info would be useful here

comments.text:
Just closed the tab and memory usage went from ~820MB down to the following. Memchaser gave me the details.

Resident: 562MB, GC: 240.0ms (9.3s), CC: 1539ms (5.7s)
comments.author: dburns@mozilla.com
comments.creator: dburns@mozilla.com

Resident: 562MB, GC: 240.0ms (9.3s), CC: 1539ms (5.7s)

comments.author: n.nethercote@gmail.com
comments.text: The site is heavy on JS usage, I suspect Chrome does better on memory consumption because of its generational garbage collector.  That's being implemented for Firefox in bug 619558.
comments.raw_text: The site is heavy on JS usage, I suspect Chrome does better on memory consumption because of its generational garbage collector.  That's being implemented for Firefox in bug 619558.
comments.creator: n.nethercote@gmail.com

comments.text: Even if with ggc, travis is still being slow with the current aurora (37).
comments.author: sledru@mozilla.com

comments.creator: julenx@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: One thing to note is Travis heavily uses SVG animations while builds are running. My CPU fan for instance always starts spinning at full speed when there are ongoing builds.
comments.author: julenx@gmail.com
comments.text: One thing to note is Travis heavily uses SVG animations while builds are running. My CPU fan for instance always starts spinning at full speed when there are ongoing builds.

comments.raw_text: This is still an issue today. Watching the dashboard of a project with many builds running at once can easily take my system to 100% CPU. It's not an issue in Safari and Chrome.
comments.text: This is still an issue today. Watching the dashboard of a project with many builds running at once can easily take my system to 100% CPU. It's not an issue in Safari and Chrome.
comments.author: tsmith84@gmail.com
comments.creator: tsmith84@gmail.com

comments.raw_text: What would help most here is a link to an actual page showing the problem....  There's not much to work with so far in this bug.
comments.text: What would help most here is a link to an actual page showing the problem....  There's not much to work with so far in this bug.
comments.author: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
tsmith84@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: https://travis-ci.org/chef/chef is an example of a Travis build dashboard. When the tests have passed the CPU usage is as expected. When the tests are running the checkboxes for each job spin and the time since the job has started increments. I'm not sure if this page is helpful when a job isn't running, but hopefully that's a starting point.
